comments:
I'm running Eclipse3.1 build 20041102 on RH WS 2.0 with J2SDK 1.4.2_04.
Fairly often - but not everytime - when I search for a String in a file, Eclipse
crashes when I click on the search button in the File Search dialog. 
Here is the output I see:

 X Error of failed request:  BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)
  Major opcode of failed request:  38 (X_QueryPointer)
  Resource id in failed request:  0x1c49406
  Serial number of failed request:  226074
  Current serial number in output stream:  226074

There is no additional information in the log file.

Chrix to investigate.  Perhaps we should get Rico to retry with 
Display.DEBUG=true to get the stack trace?
CC'ing Grant and trying to reproduce.

Can't reproduce here. 

Rico - can you paste the output of the command locale (open a terminal, type in:
locale). Thanks.

Silenio: what's the PR number requesting UI to provide a flag to enable
Display.DEBUG? Maybe I can push for it in the upcoming builds.

In case this can help, the Search button is activated from this stack trace. Not
sure if it crashes from within the selection or after though.

LC_CTYPE="en_US"

The bug request the UI is bug#74961.

Created an attachment (id=15703)
Plugin to enable debug info

Hi Rico:
To enable the debug info:
1. unzip the attachement into your eclipse folder. This creates a test_1.0.0
plugin
2. Start Eclipse
3. Go to Views > Sample Category > Sample View
You should get a debug message on the linux termminal ** ENABLED SWT DEBUG.

Now hopefully when you get the crash you will get a stack trace that you can
paste here. 

Everytime you restart Eclipse, you need to reactivate the 'Sample View' to
enable the debug info.

Where is it logged? I looked int configuration/ there is a log file, but has
nothing useful in it.
I also looked in workspace/.metadata/.log same here.

Rico

The stack traces would be displayed on the terminal  that you launched Eclipse 
from. Apparently you don't get any.

> RH WS 2.0
I have RH EL3 here, not 2.0. Maybe that matters. 

Can you run the following command to determine your GTK version (please past 
back the output):
rpm -q gtk2 glib

Forgot you're using Motif... Well please can you still give us the info about 
GTK just for our curiosity?

Wondering if upgrading to WS3 would fix things. Haven't heard of many people 
testing WS2 here.

Hmmm ... I don't see anything logged at all besides the X Error.
I'm stuck with GTK 1.x and I cannot update to WS 3.0 at the moment, otherwise I
would have used the GTK build for sure.
The code base has changed significantly since this bug was reported.  If it is still happening for you, please reopen this bug report.
